sub_topic: Finding the Ramsey number of a graph.
message_1: What is the smallest number R such that any graph on R vertices is either guaranteed to contain a complete subgraph on 3 vertices, or a subgraph with an independent set of size 3?
message_2:
The smallest number R is 6. This can be proven using Ramsey's theorem, which states that for any given integers p and q, there exists a smallest integer R(p, q) such that any graph with R(p, q) vertices will contain either a complete subgraph on p vertices or an independent set of size q.

In this case, we are looking for the smallest R such that any graph on R vertices is either guaranteed to contain a complete subgraph on 3 vertices (p = 3) or a subgraph with an independent set of size 3 (q = 3). Therefore, we want to find R(3, 3).

Ramsey's theorem can be calculated using the formula:

R(p, q) = R(p-1, q) + R(p, q-1) for p, q > 1

Using this formula, we can calculate R(3, 3) as follows:

R(3, 3) = R(2, 3) + R(3, 2)

Since R(2, q) = q and R(p, 2) = p for any p and q, we can simplify the equation:

R(3, 3) = 3 + 3 = 6

So, the smallest number R is 6. This means that any graph with 6 vertices will either contain a complete subgraph on 3 vertices or a subgraph with an independent set of size 3.
